SUMMARY:
And part of job satisfaction, in our opinion, is being recognised for the work that you do and the goals you achieve.
According to leadership and people-management specialist Karen Gately, it's even more important than your wage.
So how can you tell if you're being taken for granted at work?
Exclusion from opportunities is one sign you're not being taken seriously.
Another sign you are potentially being overlooked is if you're being excluded from opportunities.
TEXT:
They say you spend a third of your life at work (or 35 percent, according to this writer's calculations), so you'd want to hope your job is satisfying, at least from a professional point of view.

And part of job satisfaction, in our opinion, is being recognised for the work that you do and the goals you achieve.

That's not to say your superior should spend all day lavishing you with compliments (that would be weird and potentially grounds for harassment) or praising you for doing the bare minimum -- let's be real, you have to earn your stripes -- but giving credit where it's due is important.

According to leadership and people-management specialist Karen Gately, it's even more important than your wage.

"In my experience, the thank you, the pat on the back, the words of recognition are far more important than financial rewards when it comes to energising human beings," Gately told HuffPost Australia.

"If leaders aren't doing those basic steps and demonstrating appreciation for their workers, it's actually a real missed opportunity; if people feel over time that there isn't fair recognition, it drains their energy and undermines the strength of their commitment."

So how can you tell if you're being taken for granted at work?

"Obviously the most important signs of appreciation is just a thank you. Whether or not people are taking the time to look you in the eye and say 'well done and thanks for the effort'," Gately said.

Exclusion from opportunities is one sign you're not being taken seriously.

"If people aren't able to deliver on common courtesies it's a clear sign appreciation is lacking."

Another sign you are potentially being overlooked is if you're being excluded from opportunities.

"If people aren't recognising you for projects or involving you in step up opportunities, or things you feel you should be included in, that's something that might need to be addressed," Gately said.

"That's assuming you actually have whatever you think you have to offer. I mean, you have to make sure you have done the training and put the effort in to be skilled."

In terms of how to address the situation, Gately said it pays to be upfront.

Ultimately you need to choose to be in an environment where you can thrive, and if a culture is undermining that, then you have to ask whether it's worth it.

"Like any relationship, I think everything starts with an honest conversation," she said. "Your manager might not be aware for whatever reason. They might not appreciate the extent to what you feel unrecognised."

And if that doesn't work? Have a good hard think about your workplace and whether it's the right place for you.

"I think then there are decisions to make about your employer's values," Gately said. "Whether or not it's the type of environment where people are respected. Then there's a choice about whether to move on or to start change in the organisation yourself, though that will obviously depend on your position.

"Ultimately you need to choose to be in an environment where you can thrive, and if a culture is undermining that, then you have to ask whether it's worth it."
TITLE: How To Tell If You're Being Taken For Granted At Work

Pour y arriver, le gouvernement a prÃ©vu en 2018 prÃ¨s de 15 milliards d'Ã©conomies: sept pour l'Etat, avec des coupes controversÃ©es dans les aides au logement et contrats aidÃ©s notamment, cinq pour la SÃ©curitÃ© sociale, trois pour les collectivitÃ©s locales.

Cela passe mal Ã  gauche alors qu'en mÃªme temps ce budget transforme l'ISF en impÃ´t sur la seule "fortune immobiliÃ¨re" (IFI) qui, conjuguÃ©e Ã  l'introduction d'une "flat tax" de 30% sur les revenus du capital, va priver l'Etat de 4,5 milliards d'euros.

Socialistes, Insoumis, communistes dÃ©noncent un "cadeau aux plus riches". Car, souligne ValÃ©rie Rabault (Nouvelle gauche), ex-rapporteure gÃ©nÃ©rale du Budget, "plus le patrimoine d'une personne augmente, plus sa composante financiÃ¨re s'accroÃ®t".

"Je ne crois pas Ã  la jalousie franÃ§aise qui consiste Ã  dire 'il y a des riches, taxons-les, nous nous porterons mieux'", a rÃ©pondu dimanche sur TF1 Emmanuel Macron, selon qui l'ISF n'Ã©tait pas payÃ© par "les grandes fortunes" et a fait "perdre beaucoup de talents".

La RÃ©publique en Marche fait "le pari" que les FranÃ§ais aisÃ©s investiront leur Ã©pargne dans les entreprises. La chef de file LREM de la commission des Finances, AmÃ©lie de Montchalin, a "donnÃ© rendez-vous" aux banquiers et assureurs le 22 janvier Ã  l'AssemblÃ©e pour qu'ils lui remettent "une feuille de route oÃ¹ ils s'engagent Ã  crÃ©er des produits financiers en faveur des PME".

Taxe d'habitation contre CSG

En dÃ©pit des doutes exprimÃ©s y compris au sein de la majoritÃ© (le Modem prÃ©sentant un amendement pour maintenir l'ISF en excluant la dÃ©tention de titres du pÃ©rimÃ¨tre), LREM ne reviendra pas sur les principes de la rÃ©forme mais compte surtaxer des "signes extÃ©rieurs de richesse" (yachts, voitures de sport et mÃ©taux prÃ©cieux) pour Ã©viter "des effets d'aubaine", avec cependant un rendement trÃ¨s limitÃ© estimÃ© Ã  moins de 50 millions d'euros.

Hostile de longue date Ã  l'ISF, la droite, qui pourrait avoir des Ã©changes tendus avec Bruno Le Maire et GÃ©rald Darmanin, deux ministres venus de ses rangs, est dans une position inconfortable. Elle dÃ©plore que le gouvernement "ne soit pas allÃ© jusqu'au bout" en gardant l'IFI, ou ne fasse pas assez d'Ã©conomies avec 1600 postes de fonctionnaires supprimÃ©s sur 120.000 annoncÃ©s pour le quinquennat. Le parti Les RÃ©publicains se veut aussi le dÃ©fenseur des retraitÃ©s face Ã  la hausse de la CSG qui figure dans le projet de loi de financement de la SÃ©curitÃ© sociale, dont les dÃ©putÃ©s dÃ©marrent l'examen mardi en commission.

erst das PrÃ¤sidialamt und kurze Zeit spÃ¤ter auch das Parlament erstÃ¼rmte, und Kurz Ã¼berhaupt vergleichbar?
Die Gemeinsamkeitenâ–º Kurz und Macron verkaufen sich beide als Reformer und waren innerhalb kÃ¼rzester Zeit erfolgreich.
Und auch die WahlkÃ¤mpfe des 39-jÃ¤hrigen Franzosen und des 31-jÃ¤hrigen Ã–sterreichers Ã¤hnelten sich - beides waren professionelle Public-Relations-FeldzÃ¼g.

TEXT:
Bei den Wahlen in Ã–sterreich setzt sich ein Trend in Europa fort

Erfolgreich sind Politiker insbesondere dann, wenn sie mit Partei-Traditionen brechen

Doch kann so eine Erneuerung der Politik gelingen?

Sebastian Kurz hat den Gipfel der Alpenrepublik erklommen. Die WÃ¤hler hievten die Ã–sterreichische Volkspartei (Ã–VP) und damit ihren Parteichef auf das oberste Podest bei der Parlamentswahl am Sonntag.

Kurz wird wohl schon bald der jÃ¼ngste Regierungschef in Europa aller Zeiten sein, offen bleibt nur noch der Koalitionspartner.

Schon seit LÃ¤ngerem ziehen Beobachter Parallelen mit Frankreichs PrÃ¤sident Emmanuel Macron - nun verbindet beide auch der Wahlerfolg.

Doch inwiefern sind Frankreichs PrÃ¤sident, der mit seiner Bewegung "En Marche!" ("In Bewegung!") erst das PrÃ¤sidialamt und kurze Zeit spÃ¤ter auch das Parlament erstÃ¼rmte, und Kurz Ã¼berhaupt vergleichbar? Und ist ihr Erfolg ein Zeichen fÃ¼r das Ende der klassischen Parteien?

1. Die Gemeinsamkeiten

â–º Kurz und Macron verkaufen sich beide als Reformer und waren innerhalb kÃ¼rzester Zeit erfolgreich. Macrons Weg vom Underdog zum mÃ¤chtigsten Mann im Staat dauerte sechs Monate. Kurz benÃ¶tigte gar nur etwas mehr drei Monate, beginnend mit der Wahl zum Ã–VP-Obmann im Juli 2017.

â–º Angetrieben wurden beide von einer kraftvollen PR-Maschine. Und auch die WahlkÃ¤mpfe des 39-jÃ¤hrigen Franzosen und des 31-jÃ¤hrigen Ã–sterreichers Ã¤hnelten sich - beides waren professionelle Public-Relations-FeldzÃ¼g.

â–º So trat Kurz' Ã–VP gar nicht unter dem eigentlichen Namen der Partei an. Die konservative Partei ging als "Liste Sebastian Kurz - Die neue Volkspartei" in das Rennen. Neu war auch die Farbgebung: knalliges TÃ¼rkis statt muffiger GrautÃ¶ne. Die Ã–VP wollte sich farblich von ihrer Vergangenheit und den mauen Wahlergebnissen der Vergangenheit lÃ¶sen. Das gelang augenscheinlich. In Frankreich gab Macrons "En Marche!" die bereits im Namen enthaltende StoÃŸrichtung vor.

â–º Kurz' MeisterstÃ¼ck war die Ã–ffnung der Ã–VP fÃ¼r politische Quereinsteiger, die in den Augen der BÃ¼rger aus der lahmen Partei eine flotte Bewegung Ã¤hnlich der von Macron gemacht hat. Das Kabinett des franzÃ¶sischen PrÃ¤sidenten besteht aber nicht nur aus Quereinsteigern, sondern auch aus Ministern unterschiedlicher politischer Lager.

â–º Beide "Superjungstars" ("Die Welt") konnten ihren Imagewandel so weit verkaufen, als dass sie ihre Aufbruchsrhetorik trotz Regierungsbeteiligung fÃ¼r viele WÃ¤hler glaubhaft kommunizieren konnten.

â–º So ist Kurz einerseits bereits seit 2013 Ã–sterreichs AuÃŸenminister, die Ã–VP seit Mitte der 1980er Teil der Regierung, grÃ¶ÃŸtenteils als Juniorpartner. Andererseits war Macron zwischen August 2014 bis August 2016 Wirtschaftsminister unter FranÃ§ois Hollande und zuvor auch langjÃ¤hriges Mitglied der Sozialistischen Partei.

â–º AuffÃ¤llig ist ebenso, dass sowohl Macron als auch Kurz nach Bekanntgabe ihrer PlÃ¤ne in den Beliebtheitswerten nach oben schnellten. "Mit Ã–sterreichs beliebtestem Politiker an der Spitze schoss die Ã–VP in den Umfragen sofort Ã¼ber 30 Prozent an die Spitze. Vorbei an der FPÃ–, die seit der FlÃ¼chtlingskrise auf Kanzlerkurs gewesen war. So wie Macron fast spielend Marine Le Pen Ã¼berholt hatte", fasst "Die Welt" zusammen.

2. Die Unterschiede

â–º Der grÃ¶ÃŸte Unterschied ist, dass Kurz eine Alt-Partei transformierte, wÃ¤hrend Macron eine eigene Bewegung quasi von Null an aufbaute - auch ungeachtet der ÃœberlÃ¤ufer aus anderen Parteien - und erst spÃ¤ter daraus eine Partei formte.

â–º Auch politisch unterscheiden sich beide deutlich. Macron steht vor allem fÃ¼r einen sozial- und wirtschaftsliberalen Kurs. Im Vergleich dazu ist "Kurzâ€˜ gesellschaftspolitische Ausrichtung wesentlich konservativer", bemerkt der Ã¶sterreichische Politikwissenschaftler Patrick Utz im GesprÃ¤ch mit der HuffPost.

â–º Der Parteienforscher von der University of Edinburgh sagt, dass der Ã–VP-Chef einige Themen von der rechtspopulistischen FPÃ– adaptiert habe, vor allem in der FlÃ¼chtlingspolitik. "Macrons betont liberaler Kurs hingegen kann als klare Abgrenzung zum Front National verstanden werden."

3. Das Ende der Partei?

Fakt ist: Kurz hat sich vor allem symbolisch von der Ã–VP gelÃ¶st, vordergrÃ¼ndig mit der neuen Parteifarbe und einem neuem Logo.

"Ob die strukturellen Ã„nderungen, wie das ZurÃ¼ckdrÃ¤ngen des Einflusses der BÃ¼nde (Ã–VP-Teilorganisationen, Anm. d. Red.) oder Landesorganisationen, zu einer dauerhaften Umgestaltung der Partei fÃ¼hren, wird sich jetzt, erst nach der Wahl zeigen", betont Utz.

Aus seiner Sicht und mit Blick auf den Erfolg von Kurz und Macron betÃ¤tigt sich aber ein bereits lÃ¤nger zu beobachtender Trend hin zu einer "Inszenierung von Spitzenkandidaten in WahlkÃ¤mpfen".

Personen treten in den Vordergrund, Parteien und deren Programme und Ideologie spielen eine untergeordnete Rolle. Utz zufolge wÃ¼rden vor allem die neuen Medien und die sozialen Netzwerke "diesen Trend weiter beflÃ¼geln".

Der Parteienforscher erwartet allerdings keine "'Erneuerung' oder Transformation der politischen Systemen". Denn insbesondere in prÃ¤sidentiellen Systemen, wie in den USA, ist eine starke personenbezogene Politik bereits etabliert - und auch in parlamentarischen Systemen alles andere als neu.

Den grÃ¶ÃŸten Einfluss sieht er auf die Art der politischen Kommunikation. "Dem technologischen Wandel, vor allem durch Social Media, wÃ¼rde ich hier eine wesentlich grÃ¶ÃŸere Rolle zuschreiben als den handelnden Akteuren selbst."

Fazit

Zwar bescheinigte das politische Monatsmagazin "Cicero" Macron und Kurz bereits im Mai, "rebellische Kinder der Ã„ra der Parteiverdrossenheit" zu sein.

Beide seien in ihr politisch sozialisiert worden. Und beide hÃ¤tten "eine entsprechend niedrige Hemmschwelle, parteidemokratische Traditionen als Ballast zu werten und Ã¼ber Bord zu werfen".

Doch aus Sicht des "Cicero" hÃ¤tten die "Wunderpolitiker" nur eine "Rebellion von oben" gestartet. Das sei keine Demokratisierung und Ã–ffnung der Politik.

Also alles beim Alten - nur mit neuen Konzepten.



(ll)
TITLE: Kurz' Sieg hat erneut gezeigt: Der Bruch mit Partei-Traditionen bringt Erfolg - doch kann so die Politik erneuert werden?

Romain Bardet veut des Ã©tapes inÃ©dites, du spectacle et de l'incertitude pour le Tour de France 2018, qui dÃ©voile son tracÃ© mardi 17 octobre.
DÃ©jÃ  habituÃ© aux places d'honneur sur le Tour, le grimpeur de l'Ã©quipe AG2R La Mondiale visera cette annÃ©e la plus haute marche du podium sur les Champs-Ã‰lysÃ©es.
Romain Bardet Ã©tait alors redescendu Ã  la 3e place du classement gÃ©nÃ©ral, une petite seconde devant le coÃ©quipier de Froome Mikel Landa.
Et les souhaits du franÃ§ais -et du public- pourraient bien Ãªtre exaucÃ©s.
La preuve: l'ascension du Plateau des GliÃ¨res, premiÃ¨re Ã©tape de montagne du Tour, qui se terminera par deux kilomÃ¨tres sur des routes non goudronnÃ©es.
TEXT:
TOUR DE FRANCE - "Il n'y a rien de plus ennuyeux qu'une course oÃ¹ l'on sait d'avance oÃ¹ Ã§a va se jouer." Romain Bardet veut des Ã©tapes inÃ©dites, du spectacle et de l'incertitude pour le Tour de France 2018, qui dÃ©voile son tracÃ© mardi 17 octobre. Et si quelques villes-Ã©tapes sont dÃ©jÃ  connues, de nombreuses surprises sont encore Ã  attendre.

DÃ©jÃ  habituÃ© aux places d'honneur sur le Tour, le grimpeur de l'Ã©quipe AG2R La Mondiale visera cette annÃ©e la plus haute marche du podium sur les Champs-Ã‰lysÃ©es. Face Ã  lui: Chris Froome et son Ã©quipe ultra-dominatrice notamment. Le Britannique compte bien Ã©galer le record des cinq victoires dÃ©tenues par les champions Anquetil, Merckx, Hinault et Indurain.

Un adversaire imbattable? Sur un parcours attendu, sans doute, au vu de la facilitÃ© impressionnante qu'il dÃ©gage lui et son Ã©quipe. En 2017, Romain Bardet n'avait eu que trois arrivÃ©es au sommet pour tenter de dÃ©stabiliser le "Kenyan blanc", avantagÃ© par un contre-la-montre de 22,5 kilomÃ¨tres relativement plat dans les rues de Marseille la veille de l'arrivÃ©e.

Moins de contre-la-montre...

Au final, l'Auvergnat, auteur de "grands numÃ©ros" dans la montagne avait sombrÃ© face Ã  la Bonne MÃ¨re en terminant 52e de l'Ã©tape et concÃ©dant quelques 30 secondes Ã  Chris Froome arrivÃ© troisiÃ¨me. Romain Bardet Ã©tait alors redescendu Ã  la 3e place du classement gÃ©nÃ©ral, une petite seconde devant le coÃ©quipier de Froome Mikel Landa.

Lucide Ã  propos de ses atouts et de ses points faibles, le coureur revient, quelques moins aprÃ¨s, sur ce contre-la-montre dÃ©cisif: "Je suis tombÃ© sur un mauvais jour, sur une Ã©preuve qui n'est pas ma discipline favorite", concÃ¨de-t-il avant d'expliquer qu'il ne comptait par changer sa faÃ§on de courir comme l'avait fait par exemple l'autre espoir du cyclisme tricolore Thibault Pinot, en priorisant les Ã©preuves de contre la montre.

"Je n'ai pas une morphologie trÃ¨s favorable aux chronos de plat, c'est une vraie contrainte biomÃ©canique et je dois faire avec Ã§a. (...) Dans des dispositions normales, je ne prendrai jamais du temps aux favoris mais du moins je n'en perdrai pas. En tout cas je ne cÃ©derai jamais sur mes capacitÃ©s en montagne pour m'amÃ©liorer en chrono, ce n'est pas la faÃ§on dont je me suis construit en tant que cycliste", explique le grimpeur auvergnat.

...plus de montagne

En revanche, Romain Bardet et son Ã©quipe AG2R La Mondiale ont posÃ© quelques difficultÃ© Ã  Chris Froome lorsque la route s'Ã©levait. Le FranÃ§ais s'Ã©tait notamment imposÃ© au sommet de Peyragudes, dans les PyrÃ©nÃ©es, 20 secondes devant le britannique.

Pour espÃ©rer prendre le dessus sur la formation Sky et son leader -quasi- indÃ©boulonnable, l'Ã©quation est simple: moins de contre-la-montre, et plus de montagne. "On aura une premiÃ¨re partie rÃ©servÃ©e aux puncheurs, aux sprinteurs et aux coureurs de classiques, on passera ensuite Ã  la montagne et il y aura des surprises", promet Thierry Gouvenou, le directeur sportif du Tour.

La presse rÃ©gionale a Ã©voquÃ© une arrivÃ©e dans la station alpestre de La RosiÃ¨re, par les lacets de Montvalezan, Ã  la veille de l'Alpe d'Huez qui devrait Ãªtre de retour sur la carte aprÃ¨s une parenthÃ¨se de deux ans. Dans les PyrÃ©nÃ©es, aprÃ¨s une halte du cÃ´tÃ© de Carcassonne, le programme gardÃ© secret dans ses lignes principales prÃ©senterait un contre-la-montre au Pays Basque, du cÃ´tÃ© de Saint-PÃ©e-sur-Nivelle et Espelette.

Un terrain, sans doute, plus vallonnÃ© et escarpÃ© que celui de Marseille pour le grand chrono de l'Ã©dition 2017, et donc plus propice Ã  Romain Bardet. Le grimpeur pourra Ã©galement compter sur ses coÃ©quipiers pour ne pas perdre trop de temps sur les favoris lors du contre-la-montre par Ã©quipe Ã  Cholet.

Et une "course plus incertaine"

Le coureur franÃ§ais est conscient de l'ampleur de la tache qui l'attend en juillet 2018, s'il veut dÃ©trÃ´ner Christopher Froome. Il espÃ¨re ainsi une course "incertaine" qui poussera les favoris Ã  "sortir de leur zone de confort."

"Je suis favorable Ã  tout ce qui peut rendre la course plus incertaine. Il n'y a rien de plus ennuyeux qu'une course oÃ¹ l'on sait d'avance oÃ¹ Ã§a va se jouer. Il ne faut pas mettre en danger la sÃ©curitÃ© des coureurs ni transformer la course en loterie. Mais, hormis ces deux Ã©cueils, on a tous Ã  gagner Ã  ce que la course soit indÃ©cise. Les pavÃ©s, les chemins de terre, des routes difficiles Ã  l'issue incertaine, Ã§a peut permettre de rendre la course moins prÃ©visible, plus intÃ©ressante", explique-t-il.

Et les souhaits du franÃ§ais -et du public- pourraient bien Ãªtre exaucÃ©s. "Les organisateurs essayent de dÃ©sorienter les Ã©quipes car l'Ã©volution du cyclisme fait que les courses sont cadenassÃ©es", explique le directeur sportif Jean-FranÃ§ois Pescheux. La preuve: l'ascension du Plateau des GliÃ¨res, premiÃ¨re Ã©tape de montagne du Tour, qui se terminera par deux kilomÃ¨tres sur des routes non goudronnÃ©es. "Un des temps forts du Tour de France", pour son directeur Christian Prudhomme.

Confirmation doit Ãªtre donnÃ©e de confidences d'Ã©lus et de maintes rumeurs qui citent une Ã©tape de pavÃ©s du cÃ´tÃ© de Roubaix le 15 juillet, jour de la finale du Mondial de football en Russie.

Pour le reste, Romain Bardet et Warren Barguil, les hÃ©ros franÃ§ais de juillet dernier, observeront de prÃ¨s les graphiques des Ã©tapes qui leur seront proposÃ©s mardi 17 octobre tout comme Thibaut Pinot, Arnaud DÃ©mare et bien sÃ»r Christopher Froome. Rendez-vous, ensuite, le 7 juillet 2018 pour un grand dÃ©part depuis Noirmoutier en VendÃ©e.
TITLE: Parcours du Tour de France 2018: quel serait le tracÃ© idÃ©al pour Romain Bardet?

SUMMARY:
Amarinder Singh waves during a road show in favour of Congress candidate for Gurdaspur Lok Sabha bypoll Sunil Jakhar on October 9, 2017 in Gurdaspur, India.
ADVERTISEMENTMaintaining its winning streak from the assembly elections, Punjab's ruling Congress secured an emphatic win in the Gurdaspur Lok Sabha seat on Sunday.
Congress candidate Sunil Jakhar won by a margin of over 1.93 lakh votes, officials said.
He polled over 4.99 lakh votes, compared to 3.06 votes polled by Salaria.
Congress leaders and workers started had celebrating the impending victory by bursting firecrackers and distributing sweets in Gurdaspur, Chandigarh and other places even before the final result was declared.
TEXT:
Punjab Chief Minister Capt. Amarinder Singh waves during a road show in favour of Congress candidate for Gurdaspur Lok Sabha bypoll Sunil Jakhar on October 9, 2017 in Gurdaspur, India.

ADVERTISEMENT

Maintaining its winning streak from the assembly elections, Punjab's ruling Congress secured an emphatic win in the Gurdaspur Lok Sabha seat on Sunday.

Congress candidate Sunil Jakhar won by a margin of over 1.93 lakh votes, officials said. He polled over 4.99 lakh votes, compared to 3.06 votes polled by Salaria. The Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) polled only around 24,000 votes.

Jakhar, who was in the lead right from the time the vote count began on Sunday morning, extended the margin over his BJP rival Swaran Salaria after each of the 14 rounds of counting.

Congress leaders and workers started had celebrating the impending victory by bursting firecrackers and distributing sweets in Gurdaspur, Chandigarh and other places even before the final result was declared.

"We won the election because of the positive policies of the Congress. People have faith in the party," Jakhar, who was termed an 'outsider' in the constituency by his opponents, told the media after his victory

Punjab Chief Minister Amarinder Singh hailed the "unprecedented" Congress victory "as a total rejection of the anti-people policies of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) and its ally, the Shiromani Akali Dal (SAD)".

"The massive win for Congress candidate shows the people's complete denunciation of the corrupt and immoral BJP and SAD," Amarinder said, adding that it also underlined the political annihilation of the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) in the state.

"The over 1.93 lakh margin of victory has not only more than compensated for the 1.36 lakh vote defeat of Congress candidate Pratap Singh Bajwa against BJP's Vinod Khanna in 2014 but has surpassed even the 1.51 lakh lead by which Sukhbans Kaur Bhinder (Congress) had won in 1980," Amarinder pointed out.

The seat was earlier held by the BJP, which had won it in 2014. The seat fell vacant in April following the passing away of veteran actor Vinod Khanna, a four-time MP from the seat.

AAP candidate Maj. Gen. Suresh Kumar Khajuria (retd) lost his security deposit.

Khajuria left the counting centre alleging that the voting was rigged by the Congress, which came to power in the state after sweeping the assembly polls.

The counting was conducted in centres in Gurdaspur and Pathankot towns. There were 11 candidates in the fray for the October 11 election. Nearly 56 per cent of the 15.22 lakh registered voters exercised their franchise.

The voter turnout was much lower than the over 70 per cent polling in 2014.
TITLE: Big Win For Congress In Gurdaspur LS By-Poll

"Based on the information we have made the sketches, now we want cooperation from the people," the Special Investigation Team (SIT) chief, B.K.
There are two suspects and the sketches have been made by two artists based on accounts of different eyewitnesses, he said.
Lankesh was the editor of the Gauri Lankesh Patrike, a tabloid described as an "anti-establishment" publication.
Following her murder, several protests, across the country and especially in prominent parts of Karnataka, took place, leading to a stricter probe into the incident.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

BENGALURU, Karnataka -- The Special Investigation Team (SIT) of the Bengaluru Police on Friday released the sketches of the suspects in connection with the murder of journalist Gauri Lankesh.

Lankesh was shot dead at her residence by few unidentified assailants on September 5.

"Based on the information we have made the sketches, now we want cooperation from the people," the Special Investigation Team (SIT) chief, B.K. Singh, said here.

Singh said they had traced out that the suspects stayed somewhere in Bengaluru for minimum seven days, adding, "it could be more than 15 days also."

Singh further stated that they also have the video of the recce done by the suspects and they would be releasing it as well.

There are two suspects and the sketches have been made by two artists based on accounts of different eyewitnesses, he said.

Singh emphasised that they couldn't ascertain the religion of the suspects by their external appearances "like 'tilak or earrings' as they can be misleading too."

The police didn't confirm if the weapons used in murder of writer M.M. Kalburgi and Lankesh were similar.

The SIT elaborated that they had investigated 200-250 people in connection with the case.

Lankesh was the editor of the Gauri Lankesh Patrike, a tabloid described as an "anti-establishment" publication.

Following her murder, several protests, across the country and especially in prominent parts of Karnataka, took place, leading to a stricter probe into the incident.

Also on HuffPost India:
TITLE: SIT Releases Sketches Of Suspects In Gauri Lankesh's Murder

TEXT:
These snakes are commonly found throughout North and South America. They are the largest of the venomous snakes in the United States, according to the CDC. Depending on the species, they can range from one to eight feet. Be careful during hot summer nights when they are most active. They will use their rattles as a warning to you when they feel threatened. Photo Credit: Pixabay Click Here to See The Worldâ€™s Most Dangerous Snakes

Vipers snakes are found all over the world, with a few exceptions. They are quick tempered and very fast. A Vipers bite will cause immediate pain, swelling and bleeding. The Gaboon Viper specifically, has the longest fangs of any snake in the world. It likes to ambush its prey and attack by surprise. Photo Credit: Pixabay

This snake is not only one of the most venomous snakes in the world when it comes to humans, but it likes to bite other snakes as well. According to WildFacts, one bite from this snake is enough to kill you; when it bites you, its venom enters your body fast â€“ it is apparently 15 times more deadly than that of a Cobra snake. Photo Credit: Shutterstock Click Here to See The Worldâ€™s Most Dangerous Snakes

Supposedly, the Death Adder was the snake that Cleopatra used to kill herself. One bite from this venomous snake, and respiratory arrest and paralysis are likely to occur. Without treatment, 50 percent of bites usually lead to death. Photo Credit: Thinkstock

TEXT:
I Had Cervical Cancer, Now I Think All Teenagers Should Have The Opportunity To Find Out How They Can Reduce Their Risk I sat her down and asked again if she knew what the HPV vaccine was for and why it would be important for her to have it. Of course she didn't, as she hadn't learned anything about HPV and its connection to cervical cancer. Supporter of Joâ€™s Cervical Cancer Trust

Why I Am Sharing My Breast Cancer Story From 20 Years Ago When I told my family that I had found a lump, they immediately reassured me and said it was nothing to worry about. However, I decided to go to the doctor's anyways, and at first, they thought the lump was just hormonal. But when it had not gone after a month, I was quickly referred to the hospital. Mother, wife - cancer survivor

Why I Would Tell My Younger Self Not To 'Fix' My Tuberous Breasts In this vlog for HuffPost UK, Amy talks about why her breasts left her with low self-esteem and affected her mental health, but why she would now tell her younger self that 'fixing' them was not the answer, and how she wants everyone to feel comfortable with the body they are living with. Photographer and filmmaker

Will PTSD Always Be With Me? Through these winter months sometimes my world comes undone. However, hard I try to fight the memories in my mind, I can not realign my mind to the present and not the past. But, deep inside my body holds the trauma and the somatic memories. I question will I ever be free or will PTSD always be with me? Student, Running to recovery from PTSD

Many British Women Are Giving Up Sex At 40 An active, regular and exciting sex life is an important and healthy part of any adult relationship - and this isn't limited to certain stages of life. Spending intimate time with your partner can make you feel confident, sexy and loved but when you feel unable to spend this time together, for whatever reason, it can be upsetting and cause friction in the relationship. Sex & Relationship Expert

Rethinking Retouching: A Small Step Towards Realistic Imagery In The Media We still have work to do before representative imagery becomes the norm, but the new French laws are certainly a step in the right direction. And, if image providers and publishers commit to changing the status quo, we may go some way to helping future generations feel happier and more confident in their own skin. Director of Creative Insight, Getty Images

The International Day Of The Girl Is A Day For Poignant Reflection On this day, the sixth Annual Day of the Girl, I am grateful to think of the progress this Government has made and eager to see how we can shape the future opportunities for women and girls which are growing and must be taken advantage of - but I must also stress how much further there is to go. Conservative MP for Eastleigh, member of the Women and Equalities Select Committee

Natural Remedies For Endometriosis Endometriosis is one of the most common gynaecological conditions, affecting approximately 1 in 10 women. It occurs when tissue similar to the womb lining (the endometrium) grows outside of the uterus, leading to inflammation, pain and infertility. Nutritional Therapist BSc, DipION, mBANT

The Stigma Around Periods Has To End The thing about a taboo is that until someone opens it up for conversation or debate it can stay like an elephant in the room - a big issue everyone is aware of but avoids discussing or acknowledging. Once people start talking, however, taboos that have stood for decades and centuries can be quickly dismantled. Tanya Barron, OBE, is CEO of global children's charity Plan International UK

Loving The Skin You're In - Finding Your Self-Esteem Stride In Your Forties For as long as I can remember I have had problems with my skin - physically and metaphorically speaking. Singer, songwriter, blogger

Four Stories That Show Science Still Has A Gender Problem For the women themselves, it's a long-suffered truth. Statistically, women remain underrepresented in most areas of science at every level, from undergraduate courses all the way through to professorships. Despite how far we've come, there's a lot further to go, as these stories from women we met exhibiting at London's New Scientist Live exposition in September highlight. CEO & Co-founder @Sparrho (helping 150 countries stay on top of science) / @efLDN inaugural startup founder / Former @CUTEC President

Eating Disorder Recovery Graduations It is a warm September evening and I'm sat in our clinic lounge looking out at a sea of expectant faces. Some familiar, some new, many fearful, others hopeful and excited. We are at a graduation - An event that we hold in honour of each client as she reaches the end of her treatment. Entrepreneur

Why Instagram Feeds Are The New Pages Of Vogue When women are trained from childhood to crumble at the sight of their appearances, this is the first successful step of the beauty illusion. Writer, feminist and aspiring poet

Saying The Word Vagina Is Not Brave, It's NORMAL It isn't about being confident in a bikini, it's about addressing the shame, embarrassment and lack of knowledge that women routinely experience when something goes wrong inside their pelvis (ovaries, womb, cervix, vagina) or between their legs (the vulva). This is body shaming of a different kind - internal, specific to women's reproductive health and genitals. CEO of women's cancer charity, The Eve Appeal

Ireland's Big Abortion Decision In September 1983 the eighth amendment of the Constitution of Ireland was approved by referendum. This change in the law recognised the equal right to life of the mother and the unborn child even though abortion was already illegal in the country. Less than three weeks later my mother brought me into the world and I began my life in a small Irish town called Longford. Reporter for Channel 4 â€˜Unreported World'
TITLE: Womenâ€™s Issues: Trending news, opinions and blogs on female life

The Duchess of Cambridge turned to one of her favourite designers, Orla Kiely, for a surprise appearance at Paddington station in London on Monday, that saw her dancing with Paddington Bear.
It was only the second public appearance for the Duchess since Kensington Palace announced she is pregnant with her third child and was suffering with hyperemesis gravidarum - severe morning sickness.
Although the dress was already sold out on the Orla Kiely website before today, so presumably it wonâ€™t cause the usual sell out frenzy.
CHRIS J RATCLIFFE via Getty ImagesCHRIS J RATCLIFFE via Getty ImagesThe Duchess has previously worn Orla Kielyâ€™s designs to Islington Town Hall in October 2015.
EMPICS Entertainment Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, wearing an Orla Kiely dress, visits Chance UK at Islington Town HallShe also wore an Orla Kiely pleated navy skirt and MaxMara jacket at the Place2Be charity in Canary Wharf in November 2013.
TEXT:
The Duchess of Cambridge turned to one of her favourite designers, Orla Kiely, for a surprise appearance at Paddington station in London on Monday, that saw her dancing with Paddington Bear.

It was only the second public appearance for the Duchess since Kensington Palace announced she is pregnant with her third child and was suffering with hyperemesis gravidarum - severe morning sickness.

The 35-year-old arrived with her husband Prince William and brother-in-law, Prince Harry, to support a number of childrenâ€™s charities.

Watch: Dancing queen? Kate is taken for a dance by Paddington bear before she waves off a vintage train pic.twitter.com/sfxqwUg089 â€” Simon Perry (@SPerryPeoplemag) October 16, 2017

She wore the Irish brandâ€™s signature peach â€˜raised flower fitted dressâ€™, covered in applique flowers, with a black trim, which retails at Â£140.

Although the dress was already sold out on the Orla Kiely website before today, so presumably it wonâ€™t cause the usual sell out frenzy.

CHRIS J RATCLIFFE via Getty Images

The Royals met with a number of charities, as well as the cast and crew from the Paddington II film, due to be released on 10 November in the UK. Including Hugh Bonneville.

They were on the platform for a short while, before boarding the Belmond British Pullman train with a group of 130 children helped by the work of the charities such as Place2Be, East Angliaâ€™s Childrenâ€™s Hospices and Anna Freud National Centre for children.

CHRIS J RATCLIFFE via Getty Images

CHRIS J RATCLIFFE via Getty Images

The Duchess has previously worn Orla Kielyâ€™s designs to Islington Town Hall in October 2015.

And again to a Princeâ€™s Foundation event at Dulwich Picture Gallery in South London, in September 2016.

EMPICS Entertainment Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, wearing an Orla Kiely dress, visits Chance UK at Islington Town Hall

She also wore an Orla Kiely pleated navy skirt and MaxMara jacket at the Place2Be charity in Canary Wharf in November 2013.

EMPICS Entertainment
TITLE: Duchess Of Cambridge Wears Orla Kiely To Dance With Paddington Bear In Latest Public Appearance

TEXT:
The BBC has announced that its retiring â€˜Crimewatchâ€™, 33 years after the show began calling for the publicâ€™s help to solve crimes.

At the heart of the programme are its reconstructions, with actors playing victims, perpetrators and bystanders in fictional versions of everything from thefts to murder.

Over the years, hundreds of extras have starred in the segments, so it perhaps wonâ€™t come as too much of a surprise to hear that some famous faces count â€˜Crimewatchâ€™ as one of their previous credits.

While it may not be a career highlight, everyone has to start somewhere, including these celebsâ€¦

Hilda Braid

PA Archive/PA Images Hilda in 2003

Hilda won legions of fans as EastEndersâ€™ Nana Moon, but the part was just one of many that the actress landed during her career.

Long before she first stepped foot in the Queen Vic, Hilda had the task of playing a murder victim in a 1991 episode of â€˜Crimewatchâ€™.

Wendi Peters

Mark Cuthbert via Getty Images Wendi in 2005

Wendi may be famous for playing Cilla Brown in â€˜Coronation Streetâ€™, but back in 1993 she popped up in an episode of the BBC show, playing a woman who was attacked.

Marcus Bentley

Marcusâ€™s face may not be familiar, but his voice will be to many, as he provides voiceovers for â€˜Big Brotherâ€™.

Following the news that â€˜Crimewatchâ€™ is being taken off air, Marcus revealed his own link to the show on Twitter, writing: â€œMy first tv â€˜actingâ€™ job was on #crimewatch 23 years ago - I was murdered.â€

CrimeWatch axed after 33 years! My first tv â€˜actingâ€™ job was on #crimewatch 23 years ago - I was murdered. â€” Marcus Bentley (@marcusBBbentley) October 17, 2017

Dominic Brunt

ITV/REX/Shutterstock Dominic in 'Emmerdale' in 1997

The â€˜Emmerdaleâ€™ actor appeared on the oft-forgotten spin-off â€˜Crime Watch Fileâ€™, which gave viewers an insight into how the main showâ€™s criminals were caught.

â€œMy first job on screen was â€™Crime Watch File,â€ Dominic previously explained. â€œThey did a small run of one-off dramas built around solved cases which had featured on the program. I really enjoyed doing it.

â€œI didnâ€™t really care what I did as long as I was working in TV.â€

Steve Watson

Steve may not have gone on to land huge TV roles after his appearance in the show, but his story is extraordinary nonetheless.

In 1994, the jobbing actor took a part in a recreation of Julie Paceyâ€™s death, playing the criminal who sexually assaulted and strangled her.

Fast forward to 2015 when the BBC replayed the clip without his permissionâ€¦ which proved to be a bit of a problem as two people called the police and named Steve himself as the potential perpetrator.
TITLE: â€˜Crimewatchâ€™: The Famous Faces Who Starred In The Showâ€™s Reconstructions

ADVERTISEMENTLUCKNOW -- In a bid to stem the row over the Taj Mahal, Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday said the famed monument in Agra was built "by the blood and sweat of Indian labourers".
The statement came after Uttar Pradesh BJP legislator Sangeet Som sparked national outrage by calling the Mughal-built Taj Mahal a blot on Indian culture.
Adityanath is scheduled to visit the Taj Mahal, Agra Fort, Fatehpur Sikri and other important monuments in Agra on October 26, an official told IANS.
The Taj was built by Mughal emperor Shahjahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz.
Last month, the Uttar Pradesh government had omitted references to the Taj in a booklet published on the completion of six months of the Adityanath government.
TEXT:
ADVERTISEMENT

LUCKNOW -- In a bid to stem the row over the Taj Mahal, Uttar Pradesh Chief Minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday said the famed monument in Agra was built "by the blood and sweat of Indian labourers". An official said he will also visit the Taj.

"It does not matter who built it and for what reason. It was built by the blood and sweat of Indian labourers," the Chief Minister said of the 17th century marble monument which is India's biggest tourist draw.

The statement came after Uttar Pradesh BJP legislator Sangeet Som sparked national outrage by calling the Mughal-built Taj Mahal a blot on Indian culture.

Adityanath said the monument of love was important for the Uttar Pradesh government, specially "from the tourism perspective" and "it is our priority to provide facilities and safety to tourists there".

Adityanath is scheduled to visit the Taj Mahal, Agra Fort, Fatehpur Sikri and other important monuments in Agra on October 26, an official told IANS.

The Taj was built by Mughal emperor Shahjahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz. Considered one of the wonders of the world, it attracts millions of Indian and foreign tourists every year.

Last month, the Uttar Pradesh government had omitted references to the Taj in a booklet published on the completion of six months of the Adityanath government.
TITLE: Taj Mahal Is Important, Doesn't Matter Who Built It, Says Yogi Adityanath

Celui-ci s'est donc retrouvÃ© dans l'enceinte en caleÃ§on et sans t-shirt pendant toute la durÃ©e du match comme vous pouvez le voir ci-dessous.

Ce supporter de l'OM Ã  cÃ´tÃ© de moi a donc Ã©tÃ© forcÃ© Ã  retirer son ensemble de l'OM et donc entrer torse nu et en caleÃ§on au stade ! Honteux. pic.twitter.com/0Wu8bRYja7 15 octobre 2017

ContactÃ© par Le HuffPost, l'auteur du clichÃ©, Mathieu Lauricella, explique: "J'ai vu un des responsables sÃ©curitÃ© demander Ã  un supporter de l'OM Ã  l'intÃ©rieur du stade de retirer son maillot en disant 'Ã§a nous Ã©vitera des problÃ¨mes, je sais que ce n'est pas normal mais ce sont les consignes'".

Selon ce tÃ©moin, le service d'ordre a Ã©tÃ© intransigeant: "D'aprÃ¨s ce que les personnes concernÃ©es, elles n'ont pas eu d'autre choix que de retirer leurs vÃªtements OM si elles voulaient rentrer."

L'homme prÃ©sent sur le clichÃ© n'est donc pas le seul fan olympien Ã  s'Ãªtre vu demander d'enlever ses habits marquÃ©s du sigle OM. "Certaines personnes ont dÃ» mettre leurs habits Ã  l'envers (notamment des enfants). Un autre fan a dÃ» repartir chez lui chercher d'autres vÃªtements."

Un autre supporter forcÃ© Ã  retirer son maillot ! "Ã‡a nous Ã©vitera des problÃ¨mes" selon le responsable. C'est une honte ! pic.twitter.com/8IYBLvyJsM â€” Mathieu Lauricella (@LauricellaMatt) 15 octobre 2017

Ah et il y avait aussi un pÃ¨re avec ses deux gamins qui ont dÃ» retourner leurs bas de survÃªt' de l'OM pour entrer. Des minots quoi... â€” Mathieu Lauricella (@LauricellaMatt) 16 octobre 2017

Le club strasbourgeois a justifiÃ© cette consigne par un impÃ©ratif sÃ©curitaire: "On avait incitÃ© les fans de l'OM Ã  ne pas trop s'exhiber, pour ceux qui n'Ã©taient pas en parcage visiteur. C'Ã©tait un conseil", explique le secrÃ©taire gÃ©nÃ©ral du club strasbourgeois Romain Giraud au HuffPost, avant de raconter la scÃ¨ne: "avant le dÃ©but du match (Ã  1-2 heures du coup d'envoi), il y a eu des incidents aux abords de la Meinau entre des Marseillais et des forces de l'ordre."

"L'objectif a alors consistÃ© Ã  Ã©viter des incidents dans le stade et surtout Ã  prÃ©venir le risque. Il s'agissait principalement d'une mesure de prÃ©vention. Cela a donnÃ© une sÃ©quence qui est Ã©videmment regrettable avec ce monsieur qui Ã©tait initialement habillÃ© aux couleurs marseillaises de la tÃªte aux pieds. A ce titre, je tiens Ã  prÃ©ciser que c'Ã©tait pour lui, pour sa sÃ©curitÃ©, et plus gÃ©nÃ©ralement la sÃ©curitÃ© de tout le monde dans l'enceinte", explique le secrÃ©taire gÃ©nÃ©ral.

Ã€ ce titre, il convient de prÃ©ciser que le parcage visiteur rÃ©servÃ© aux fans marseillais Ã©tait complet, les supporters de l'OM prÃ©sents dans l'enceinte ne pouvaient donc pas Ãªtre redirigÃ©s en tribune visiteur.

Selon Mathieu Lauricella, des spectateurs Ã©taient vÃªtus de maillots d'autres clubs dans l'enceinte, causant l'incomprÃ©hension: "D'autres supporters portaient des maillots d'autres clubs (du PSG et de l'Inter, entre autres) et ces personnes lÃ  ont pu entrer sans problÃ¨me et sans devoir les enlever. Il y a eu de l'incomprÃ©hension et un sentiment d'injustice assez lÃ©gitime."

Une mesure devenue finalement banale

Cependant, ce n'est pas la premiÃ¨re fois que des supporters se voient obligÃ©s d'enlever leurs vÃªtements dans des stades de football en France. En mai dernier, lors du dÃ©placement de l'OM Ã  Angers, certains fans olympiens avaient Ã©tÃ© contraints d'enlever ou de cacher leurs vÃªtements OM comme l'Ã©voquait 20 Minutes. Ces derniers ne se trouvaient pas en tribune visiteur.

En aoÃ»t dernier, lors de la 4Ã¨me journÃ©e du championnat, l'OM se dÃ©plaÃ§ait Ã  Monaco. Le club de la PrincipautÃ© avait ainsi dÃ©taillÃ© sur son site officiel: "A noter Ã  titre informatif, dimanche, que toutes personnes vÃªtues d'un maillot autre que celui de AS Monaco (ou Olympique de Marseille en tribune visiteurs exclusivement), se verra refuser l'accÃ¨s aux tribunes du stade Louis-II."

Il y a deux semaines, en marge du dÃ©placement de l'OM Ã  Nice, un arrÃªtÃ© prÃ©fectoral a Ã©tÃ© Ã©mis afin "d'inciter Ã  la discrÃ©tion les Marseillais" comme l'a relayÃ© Nice-matin: "En raison des contraintes de sÃ©curitÃ© actuelles, et pour Ã©viter tout trouble Ã  l'ordre public, autrement dit toute provocation envers les supporteurs niÃ§ois, les fans de l'OM n'ont pas intÃ©rÃªt Ã  sortir des drapeaux et autres fumigÃ¨nes aux abords du stade."

Plus globalement, ces impÃ©ratifs sÃ©curitaires ne sont pas nouveaux dans les stades franÃ§ais et ne sont pas nÃ©cessairement rÃ©servÃ©s aux fans de l'OM . En marge du match France-Allemagne disputÃ© en 2013, aucun spectateur ne pouvait se rendre au stade de France avec... un vÃªtement Ã  l'effigie du PSG comme l'expliquait Le Parisien.

Ã€ voir Ã©galement sur Le HuffPost:

SUMMARY:

Research by the Resolution Foundation think-tank warns dairy, meat and clothes prices will soar if the UK is unable to strike a trade deal with the EU.

TEXT:
The UKâ€™s poorest families will be at least Â£500-a-year worse off with a â€˜no dealâ€™ Brexit, a new study has claimed.

Research by the Resolution Foundation think-tank warns dairy, meat and clothes prices will soar if the UK is unable to strike a trade deal with the EU.

Reverting to World Trade Organisation tariffs would see the average price of dairy goods rising by 8.1 per cent, meat products by 5.8 per cent and transport vehicles by 5.5 per cent.

The report, carried out with academics at Sussex University, claims this would see three million families hit with a Â£500-a-year levy, while the average household would be stung to the tune of Â£260.

Theresa May has repeatedly claimed that no deal with the EU is better than a bad deal, and last week the Government began publishing detailed reports on how UK customs and trade policy would operate if no agreement is signed.

Ilona Serwicka, a Research Fellow at the UK Trade Policy Observatory at the University of Sussex, argued that â€˜no dealâ€™ would impact the poorest households the hardest.

She said: â€œTo avoid the real economic danger of a â€˜cliff-edgeâ€™ scenario â€“ that will see the cost of living for households up and down the country go up â€“ the UK Government must realise that walking away from the negotiating table is the worst possible outcome.â€

Want to know whatâ€™s really going on with Brexit? Sign up for HuffPost UKâ€™s Brexit Briefing - sent straight to your inbox every Thursday.

Stephen Clarke, Economic Analyst at the Resolution Foundation, added: â€œWhile trade may not have been the biggest issue in the referendum it is one that will affect the day-to-day living standards of every family in Britain. The government must rightly continue to prioritise a comprehensive new trade agreement with the EU in order to avoid households having to fork out for a â€˜no dealâ€™ outcome through higher prices and squeezed households budgets.â€

According to the the study, imposing most-favoured nation (MFN) tariffs on the EU would see the cost of importing dairy products imports rise by 45%, meat by 37 per cent, and clothing, footwear, beverages and tobacco by 10 per cent.

By the time the products hit shop shelves, much of the extra cost will have been absorbed, but it will still lead to an almost Â£10-a-week rise in prices for the poorest families.

In the Customs Bill published on October 9, the Government stated that if the UK leaves the EU without a negotiated settlement it â€œwould apply the same customs duty to every country with which it does not have a trade deal or otherwise provide preferential access to the UK market, such as schemes for developing countriesâ€.

Stephen Doughty MP, supporter of anti-Brexit campaign group Open Britain, said: â€œItâ€™s clear that the no-deal Brexit Theresa May is threatening will make working people in this country worse off, with the very poorest paying the price for the Governmentâ€™s ideological choice of a hard and extreme Brexit.

â€œLeaving the EU with no deal will erect massive barriers to trade. Given that we import 20 per cent of all the food we eat from Europe, this will make the weekly shop more expensive for working families.â€

Reuters Photographer / Reuters Theresa May and David Davis travelled to Brussels for dinner with Jean-Claude Juncker.

The study comes just hours after Theresa May and David Davis held a private dinner with European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker in a bid to kick-start progress on the Brexit negotiations.

At the end of the fifth round of talks in Brussels last week, the EUâ€™s chief negotiator Michel Barnier said there was â€œdeadlockâ€ over how much the UK should pay in a financial settlement when it leaves the bloc in March 2019.

The EU has vowed not to begin trade talks â€“ which could avoid a â€˜hard Brexitâ€™ â€“ until â€œsufficient progressâ€ has been made on the issue.

Last night, Theresa May and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker agreed to â€œaccelerateâ€ stalled Brexit talks amid fears that a deadlock could harm both the UK and EU.

The Prime Minister and Juncker issued a rare joint statement stressing that their working dinner in Brussels on Monday night had been â€œconstructive and friendlyâ€.

Labourâ€™s Shadow Brexit Minister Jenny Chapman MP said the Resolution Foundation report showed the â€œpotential dire consequences of the Governmentâ€™s chaotic handling of the Brexit negotiations.â€

She added: â€œBritain crashing out of Europe without a deal is simply not a viable option. No deal risks price hikes in the shops as a result of extra charges on everyday items, such as food and drink. And yet, the only solution Ministers have offered to this potential crisis is â€˜dig for no dealâ€™.

â€œTheresa May must use this weekâ€™s EU Council meeting to end the deadlock in Brexit negotiations and protect Britain from an economic cliff edge. That means agreeing strong transitional arrangements within the single market and a customs union.â€

Tory MP Maria Caulfield MP hit back, saying: â€œLabourâ€™s willingness to accept any deal the EU offers would sell Britain short.

â€œLimiting our options and refusing to plan for all possible outcomes makes it harder to negotiate the good deal that we all want.
TITLE: 'No Deal' Brexit Will Leave Poorest Families Â£500-A-Year Worse Off, Claims Report

SUMMARY:
I Wrote The Article About The AfD That Ukip Said Showed It Wasn't Far-Right.
A hung parliament and a weakened Conservative Prime Minister, combined with an unexpected rise in support for the Labour Party was the apparent, take-away result.
On June 8th, make history once more - break the establishment, vote Labour - and change this country forever.
But given Theresa May's rhetoric since becoming Prime Minister, pitching to UKIP voters, it's clear why UKIP would have little reason to oppose the Conservatives.
UKIP and their kind are constantly targeting people who just want to get on with their lives.
TEXT:
I Wrote The Article About The AfD That Ukip Said Showed It Wasn't Far-Right. Here's Why They're Wrong Ukip thinks Germany's AfD isn't far-right. They seemed to learn this from a 'left wing Huffington Post' article I wrote, which was read out at conference as proof the AfD is perfectly sensible. Here's why I disagree. Assistant News Editor, HuffPost UK

The Triumphalism Of Corbyn's Conference t's entirely possible the Lib Dems or even UKIP could revive support under new leadership in a snap election, to assume that it would result in an almost automatic victory for Labour is a very dangerous thing indeed, if recent events are anything to go by. Aspiring journalist with a passion for news, current affairs and politics

Just Words, Or Freedom At Risk? "It's only words, and words are all I have, to take your heart away" Let's hope that this is the first, last, and only time that I ever quote the lyr... UKIP MEP for the North East of England

The 2017 Challenge For GCSE Students? Explaining What Their Results Mean The real worry for every teacher though? Once the changes have finally come in, some bright spark in government might well decide to change the whole thing all over again. Politicians like changing things, you see. Sometimes though the best thing to do is leave everything well alone - and allow teachers sufficient time to become experts in what they're teaching. UKIP MEP for the North East of England

A Nation In The Grip Of Populism... Yet Again Just over three weeks ago we as a nation witnessed an extraordinary election. A hung parliament and a weakened Conservative Prime Minister, combined with an unexpected rise in support for the Labour Party was the apparent, take-away result. More deeply however this election epitomised a manifestation of anger against the system. An anger that we have seen before. Politics & History Graduate from the University of Hull - Supporter of PR @MakeVotesMatter, Christian & Londoner.

DisMayed You will all remember from school science lessons that two minuses make a plus. Not in politics it seems. Westminster based political consultant. Associate Director with JBP.

What Now For Ukip? Now searching for their fifth leader in a year, Ukip find themselves in a precarious position. An inability to present themselves as a credible "protector" of Brexit will only see them lose further relevance, resulting in a party that won 12.6% of the vote in 2015 becoming all but wiped out by the time of the next general election. Farage has hinted at another potential comeback, and it could well prove to be that Ukip's survival is dependent on the return of their biggest beast. Journalist and political scientist

This Vote Will Go Down In History As 'The Brexit Election' We've heard many times that 'Brexit means Brexit' but with negotiations with the EU scheduled to start just 11 days after the vote, in the next two weeks we should all be clearer on what Brexit really means. Head of Birmingham City University's Centre for Brexit Studies.

Letter To Ukip Voters: Make History Once More On Thursday, take one last swipe at the elites - Re-Brexit this country - take back the power they stole from you and prove - yet again - that the establishment will not dictate the course of this country and it is we - the people - who will determine its future. On June 8th, make history once more - break the establishment, vote Labour - and change this country forever. Politics. Campaigns. Analysis.

I Want The Lib Dems To Be Kingmakers, Not EU Lobbyists The perception of a single issue has caused sliding polls for the SNP and the desecration of UKIP as they have become assimilated into the Conservatives. Lib Dem campaigner in Cambridge, bodyman for Susan van de Ven. Toby Ziegler wannabe.

Six Policies In Ukip's Manifesto That Are Actually Pretty Good (And One That Was Mysteriously Dropped) If you can get past the headlines and random mentions of Vitamin D deficiency in a policy about cultural integration, Ukip's manifesto contains a few gems which even the most ardent left-winger would struggle to argue with. UKIP MEP for the North East of England

Forget The 'Progressive Alliance', A UKIP-Conservative Alliance Is Already Happening Clearly this isn't a formal 'alliance' like the SDP-Liberal Alliance or other such electoral pacts, and a lot of it comes down to the simple fact that UKIP can't muster the candidate numbers to fight every seat. But given Theresa May's rhetoric since becoming Prime Minister, pitching to UKIP voters, it's clear why UKIP would have little reason to oppose the Conservatives. Aspiring journalist with a passion for news, current affairs and politics

I Will Not Stop Challenging Ukip's Racism This call has nothing to do with defending women's rights. It has everything to do with UKIP demonising the Muslim community, just like in France last year when politicians campaigned to ban the Birkini. Why should anyone have the right to tell Muslim women what to wear? UKIP and their kind are constantly targeting people who just want to get on with their lives. It shows the nature of their party, it shows their racism. Student and Stand Up To Racism campaigner.

Burka Ban Or The Start Of A UK Muslim Ban? Most people cannot comprehend the magnitude of telling someone to remove a religious article of clothing. The burka is not just a piece of cloth. It is a part of an identity. Worn with the understanding of the creed and for the love of religion. There is a spiritual and emotional connection. By having a ban implemented, it will create further barriers preventing the interaction between the wider social group and stigmatising the minority. Writer, Reader, Tea drinker

Brexit, The NHS And The Question Of Which Leader Is Fit To Govern Will Dominate The General Election Campaign May will continue to maintain that a vote for her is a vote for economic stability and a secure Brexit process. On the other hand the PM will assert that a vote for Corbyn's Labour is a vote for a divisive and unstable government propped up in coalition by Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP, and the Lib Dems. This message will resonate with vast swathes of the electorate. Senior Political Consultant at the Whitehouse Consultancy
TITLE: UKIP news, updates, analysis, interviews with party members, video

SUMMARY:
Sometimes you just don't want to put a lot of effort into Halloween.
What with work, your social life, kids, watching "Riverdale" on Netflix, and eating (we spend a lot of time eating), there's little time left for making a Halloween costume or going to several stores trying to find your outfit.
But sometimes, you don't have much of a choice.
Whether it's for the office group Halloween costume contest or just a party you're going to with some friends, you have to dress up, even if you aren't in the Halloween spirit.
So, for all those lazy folks out there, we picked some easy Halloween costumes that don't require much effort.
TEXT:
Sometimes you just don't want to put a lot of effort into Halloween. And we get that. What with work, your social life, kids, watching "Riverdale" on Netflix, and eating (we spend a lot of time eating), there's little time left for making a Halloween costume or going to several stores trying to find your outfit.

But sometimes, you don't have much of a choice. Whether it's for the office group Halloween costume contest or just a party you're going to with some friends, you have to dress up, even if you aren't in the Halloween spirit.

So, for all those lazy folks out there, we picked some easy Halloween costumes that don't require much effort.

SUMMARY:
â€œTheyâ€™re not fighting for your right to speak Spanish,â€ the teacher says in the video.
The teacher insisted that if Vianery wanted to speak her language, she could do so in Spanish class.
So Vianery was kicked out for not speaking â€œAmerican.â€â€œI laughed, because, first of all, thatâ€™s not a language,â€ Vianery told NBC Latino.
â€œI have the right to speak Spanish.
I have the right to speak whatever language I speak, and thatâ€™s my right.
TEXT:
New Jersey high school students on Monday decided to walk out in protest after a teacher last week insisted that a student speaking Spanish should instead â€œspeak American.â€

Students at Cliffside Park High School in Cliffside Park, New Jersey, recorded a teacher on Thursday insisting that United States soldiers were not fighting for the right to speak a language other than English. Junior Vianery Cabrera, 16, told NBC Latino that she was discussing the New York Yankees in Spanish with a friend when the teacher snapped.

â€œTheyâ€™re not fighting for your right to speak Spanish,â€ the teacher says in the video. â€œTheyâ€™re fighting for your right to speak American.â€

In the video, the teacher kicked the students out and yelled that they were being â€œdisrespectfulâ€ as they grabbed their belongings and left the classroom. After the video spread, more students became angered and about 100 students chose to walk out on Monday in protest.

The United States does not have an official language.

Vianery moved to the U.S. three years ago from the Dominican Republic and is more comfortable speaking Spanish. The teacher insisted that if Vianery wanted to speak her language, she could do so in Spanish class.

So Vianery was kicked out for not speaking â€œAmerican.â€

â€œI laughed, because, first of all, thatâ€™s not a language,â€ Vianery told NBC Latino. â€œI have the right to speak Spanish. I have the right to speak English. I have the right to speak whatever language I speak, and thatâ€™s my right. Thereâ€™s no law that says that I should or I must speak English.â€

A Snapchat video of the incident circulated on Monday, and students took a stand by walking out of school. About 100 students left on their own, and then a fire alarm was pulled forcing the entire school to evacuate, NBC Latino reported.
TITLE: High Schoolers Protest After Teacher Tells Student To Speak 'American'

SUMMARY:
Labour MP for MidlothianHanging Out On The Fringes - Labour Conference 2017 The Labour Party has a tradition of inviting pre-eminent international speakers to address its conference.
Labour activist and Chair of LGBT Labour WalesOn World Mental Health Day, We Must Commit To Fair Funding For Mental Health Care Mental health is on the TV.
Labour MP for Bootle and Shadow Chief Sec to the TreasuryOnly Labour Can Deliver The Transport Investment Britain Needs The Conservatives are refusing to say precisely where the Â£400 million of transport investment will be spent.
Labour MP for Blaenau Gwent and party whipDisability Activists Challenging Labour Disabled people are making sure their voices and viewpoints are heard.
Labour MP for East Leeds, Shadow Justice Secretary
TEXT:
The Government Must Do More To Protect Young Lives From Meningitis Meningitis Now are just one charity who do amazing work in raising awareness and campaigning for policy changes around the disease. I will be meeting with them and Izzy's father this week to film a video which is intended to increase awareness of meningitis among parents and young people ahead of Meningitis Student Awareness Week (22 -29 October). Labour MP for Bristol East

I Shouldn't Have To Help My Constituents Call The Universal Credit Helpline - The Government Must Make It Free The simple act of offering my phone to constituents is politics on the front line, and I won't turn anyone away who needs help and support. The Governments' refusal to scrap this charge shows their lack of understanding of the everyday lives and hardships of those who are struggling on their new benefit service. I hope that elected representatives across the country can do the same as I have and offer their phone up for free to contact the Universal Credit helpline. If Theresa May won't make seeking help free, then until we make her change her mind on this, and on Universal Credit in general, we should do what little things we can to help people in need. Labour MP for Midlothian

Hanging Out On The Fringes - Labour Conference 2017 The Labour Party has a tradition of inviting pre-eminent international speakers to address its conference. President Bill Clinton did it twice in 2002 and 2006, and the late, great, Nelson Mandela addressed the conference in Brighton in 2000. Acting Senior UK Political Adviser at Christian Aid. Previously worked in health policy, UK Parliament & UK civil service.

Why Coming Out Still Matters This Wednesday, 11th October, is National Coming Out Day, a date popularised in the USA but frequently marked here in the UK too. People use it as an opportunity to come out for the first time, to share their coming out story, or just to promote being out and being part of the LGBT community. But why do we still need to come out? It's 2017. Aren't we done with all that? Labour activist and Chair of LGBT Labour Wales

On World Mental Health Day, We Must Commit To Fair Funding For Mental Health Care Mental health is on the TV. On the radio. In the tabloids, in the broadsheets, in the magazines. Online. Mental health is on everyone's lips; Prime Ministers and future kings. Mental health is what everyone seems to be talking about. It's time to talk. It's good to talk. That really is something to celebrate. We are all talking about mental health - and yet ... and yet the talk is increasingly of crisis. We must ring-fence mental health spending to close the gap between the rhetoric of parity and the reality of cuts on the front-line. We must keep talking. But if we want to see real equality for mental health now is the time for action. Labour and Co-operative MP for Liverpool Wavertree, President of Labourâ€™s Campaign for Mental Health

No Hope For Young People From Hapless Hammond The reality is that young people in this country have felt the brunt of seven years of Tory austerity. Rising house prices, slow economic growth, and a lack of stable employment have entrenched huge economic inequality between the younger and older generations. Under the Conservatives, the levels of debt young people find themselves in has risen dramatically. The decision to triple tuition fees and end grants for students attending university now means that young people are leaving university with on average Â£40,000 worth of debt. Labour MP for Bootle and Shadow Chief Sec to the Treasury

Only Labour Can Deliver The Transport Investment Britain Needs The Conservatives are refusing to say precisely where the Â£400 million of transport investment will be spent. Why make an announcement without a plan? The reason is that this is a government without a plan, and merely shows how out of the touch the Tories are with the needs and ambitions of the North. Shadow transport secretary and Labour MP for Middlesborough

7,000 Words And Not A Single Mention Of Wales After this conference season, it's becoming increasingly clear that Theresa May is content with providing "second best" solutions to the issues which face communities across Wales and the UK as a whole. Member of Parliament for Ogmore

Tory Conference Diary, Day 4: May's Disaster Of A Speech Proved The Tories Have No Plan As Tory Conference comes to a close many of the papers and broadcast channels have obviously focused in on the mishaps which plagued Theresa May's speech. But aside from the cough and the falling backdrop, the true disaster of the speech lies in the fact that we had final confirmation that the Tories really do have no plan. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Southern Rail Dispute And Uber Debacle Shows Labour Will Fight For The Unions, Not You The strikes on Tuesday and Thursday by the RMT Union have caused yet more indignation for so many of my constituents in East Surrey who commute into London for work and all the other passengers reliant on the service. What makes it all the more galling for the passengers is the persistent support the unions receive from Jeremy Corbyn. Rather than condemning the union bosses for playing games, the Labour leader has made it abundantly clear he stands with the union barons. Prisons and probation minister and Conservative MP for East Surrey

Tory Conference Diary, Day 3: Do They Have Even A Semblance Of A Plan For Britain? With one day left, it's down to Theresa May to put forward her vision for the future and prove she has a semblance of a plan. If the last three days are anything to go by, I think the Tory faithful are going to be leaving Manchester very disappointed. Labour MP for Hemsworth and Shadow Minister for the Cabinet

Amazon's Tax Crackdown Is The First Step To Fairness This one-off payment means hundreds of millions more for public services and taxpayers across the continent. Schools, hospitals, front line services and infrastructure all benefiting from the success of these big companies. Surely that's how it should always work, and a state of affairs worth striving for? Labour MP for Blaenau Gwent and party whip

Disability Activists Challenging Labour Disabled people are making sure their voices and viewpoints are heard. There is no excuse for lack of accessibility and a failure to consult. Disabled people must advise on conference planning. I am involved in both groups, we are working together. Our activism and solidarity will enable us to succeed. Disability Blogger Activist & Information Guru. Wheelchair user passionate about equality inclusion & education. Lover of books & cats.

Help To Buy Will Help To Bury Home Ownership, And The Tories' Hopes For A Political Resurgence With It Tackling the housing crisis will take time, reform won't deliver immediate benefits and will need longer than one parliamentary term to make a real difference. Yet instead of offering the bold reform needed the Conservatives have gone for the easy option. But Help to Buy is not the answer, instead it will help to bury the next generation's aspirations for home ownership and the Tories' hopes for a political resurgence with it. Senior Research Fellow at IPPR, specialising in housing and infrastructure

The Conservatives Have Run Out Of Ideas Of How To Repair Our Broken Justice System Crisis after crisis rocked the justice system this summer. Conservative Justice Secretary David Lidington had an opportunity to show that he was getting a grip during his keynote speech at Conservative Party conference. Sadly for the millions who depend on a properly functioning justice system, he fluffed his chance. Labour MP for East Leeds, Shadow Justice Secretary
TITLE: Labour Party

SUMMARY:
I feel it, I am a target of it and have almost certainly been an agent of it albeit unwittingly.
Veteran campaignerWere Donald Trump's Days In Wrestling A Dress Rehearsal For Being President?
As President, Donald Trump has certainly done that.
Donald Trump And The Great NFL Distraction One of the more fun types of play you'll see during any NFL game, is the play-action pass.
Join the conversation at www.facebook.com/ThePoliticalDivaDonald Trump Is No Liar In many of Trump's outpourings, "False" is far more obvious than "Statement".
TEXT:
Nobel Peace Prize: A Win For The Nuclear Ban Nuclear weapon states will soon see that it is unrealistic to continue to keep such horrific, indiscriminate, expensive weapons - costing the U.K. a mere Â£100,000,000,000 annually - money that could be better spent elsewhere. In this new era where conflict is taking on a new guise, where conflict comes more and more in the form of terrorism and cyber threats; archaic weapons like this one are not designed to tackle modern-day challenges. WMD Ambassador who would like to see policy changes in the area of disarmament, active security enthusiast, Tweets are all my opinion and agreement

Retweeting Away Our Liberty I do not want to sound like a flat earth swivel-eyed fool. I believe in the moon landings. I have seen behind the curtain and there is no lizards back there. I am absolutely certain however about the truth of a raging Cold War being waged online. I feel it, I am a target of it and have almost certainly been an agent of it albeit unwittingly. As have you. Labour MP for Birmingham Yardley

The White House Babbler The US secretary of state Rex Tillerson is reported to have called Trump 'a (expletive deleted) moron' after a meeting in which the president apparently suggested that the US should increase its nuclear arsenal ten-fold. So in future, when Tillerson seeks to reassure nervous allies abroad, I suggest he simply tells them that the Babbler-in-Chief is babbling again, and they should take no notice. Journalist and broadcaster

Hip Hop Artists Take A Knee To Trump And Police Brutality Enter hip-hop, a genre that has never just been about the music: it has always kept a steady connection to blackness, immortalised by Public Enemy frontman Chuck D as "the Black CNN." It is hardly surprising that hip-hop artists have gathered in vocal support of Kaepernick's stand, and in powerful opposition to Trump's careless and divisive remarks. Recent graduate, hopeful music writer

I Am Trying To Understand America I know, I should probably be concentrating on trying to understand Britain first - we have plenty of problems of our own with Brexit and Boris and backstabbing. But sometimes, it's easier to deal with someone else's problems that face up to your own, isn't it? Which is why I'm trying to understand America but it's hard. Mother, Writer and London Geek

Could Ballroom Dancing Be About To Give Us The Feud To End All Feuds? Shirley couldn't resist once again laying into the routine dreamt up by Brendan. The ensuing couple of minutes, when it appeared as if they may actually come to blows, definitely made for uncomfortable, yet weirdly compulsive viewing. Would be multi-millionaire, would be celebrated writer- sadly neither (yet)

The US Doesn't Just Need Gun Control - It Needs A Massive Change In Attitude Without stricter controls, gun culture won't change. And without a radical change in attitudes to guns, some Americans will continue to use their right to own firearms to take the lives of innocent women, men and children. Reads, writes and speaks about healthcare, current affairs and social issues.

The Battle Of Ideas And Arguments: Unions, Guns, Trump And America I've never found it that easy to know what the 'right' question is when confronting an issue, it has always been more of a visceral search in the dark, guided by instinct rather than reason. But, following on from my last piece, it isn't just the questions that are important, why and how you frame an argument can be absolutely critical and have unintended consequences. Veteran campaigner

Were Donald Trump's Days In Wrestling A Dress Rehearsal For Being President? In wrestling, when characters are successful they describe them as taking their own real personality and "turning the dial up to 100". As President, Donald Trump has certainly done that. Host of The World According To Wrestling

The Power Of The Platform Social networking. Society's greatest bastion of opinion, debate and argument. Whether it's a president venting (probably) from the toilet, a Kardashian's ovaries or your friend's dad who keeps posting articles on immigration that maybe, might be, definitely are racist, you'll be hard-pressed to find an access point to opinions as immediate and extensive as a social network. Student + Writer at UoY. Sport Editor for The Yorker.

Donald Trump And The Great NFL Distraction One of the more fun types of play you'll see during any NFL game, is the play-action pass. It is an elaborate fake, involving the QB pretending to hand the ball to the running back while actually concealing the fact they have kept the ball and intend to throw it downfield for a touchdown. When it's done well it's deadly, making the defender think one thing is going on, when they should be worried about something else entirely. Brand Journalist at Hill + Knowlton Strategies Sports and Partnership Marketing

If Trump Wants To Reform The United Nations For The Better, Here's What He Could Do "The United Nations has not reached its full potential because of bureaucracy and mismanagement," said Donald Trump last week in New York, flanked b... Head of the UN staff union in Geneva

A Bluster Of Words: Trump And Kim Jong-Un There will be a time when the tensions will be played out but until that time, I will keep speaking out against human rights whilst still maintaining my passion for adventures. We should raise our children to be Otto Warmbier's rather than Trumps/Kim Jong-un's. LLB Law Grad

Take A Knee A flag is just a piece of cloth. What it's supposed to represent - an equal playing field for all, justice for all - is not being adhered to and has not been, ever, in the history of the US. Join the conversation at www.facebook.com/ThePoliticalDiva

Donald Trump Is No Liar In many of Trump's outpourings, "False" is far more obvious than "Statement". But it's the other two that are tricky. Does he knowingly intend to deceive, or does he simply say whatever advances his own world view and boosts his ego? Officially Endorsed by the President of the United States... I wish that were a good thing
TITLE: Donald Trump: News, satire and everything you need to know about Donald Trump

SUMMARY:
Yes, yes we KNOW the world is ending, there is real news happening, we get it.
pic.twitter.com/AIGNpcJn6G â€” Jesse McLaren (@McJesse) October 15, 2017The tweet absolutely exploded because, let's be honest, how is she balancing like that?
Even Ariana Grande herself weighed in, basically begging the internet to prove it's possible.
next week on mythbusters https://t.co/1tgyXtfyC6 â€” Ariana Grande (@ArianaGrande) October 16, 2017And thus a trend was born.

TEXT:
Yes, yes we KNOW the world is ending, there is real news happening, we get it. But look, all around the world people are ignoring the constant and suffocating feeling of doom that has become synonymous with 2017 and are uniting to figure out one thing: How is Ariana Grande perching on a stool in her 'My Everything' Album cover?

It all started with BuzzFeed's Jesse McLaren posting the following on twitter:

I've done the research and there's no way her ass is sitting on that stool. pic.twitter.com/AIGNpcJn6G â€” Jesse McLaren (@McJesse) October 15, 2017

The tweet absolutely exploded because, let's be honest, how is she balancing like that? It's very precarious, yet she seems so comfortable. Could it be done?

Even Ariana Grande herself weighed in, basically begging the internet to prove it's possible.

next week on mythbusters https://t.co/1tgyXtfyC6 â€” Ariana Grande (@ArianaGrande) October 16, 2017

And thus a trend was born.

idk man i tested it out pic.twitter.com/R0lcdOwSnI â€” kennyğŸ•¸ (@Slhut) October 16, 2017

No not photo shopped my mate didn't photo shop pic.twitter.com/b9zKniDVMK â€” Spooky Kimiana ğŸŒ¹ğŸŒ™ (@agbxdangerous) October 16, 2017

There were also receipts uncovered to reveal that, despite claims of photoshop magic, Grande definitely was sitting on a stool at the time of the photo shoot, she was not -- as far as we can tell -- practicing some kind of stool based witchcraft or wizardry.

LOLğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜‚ believe it or not she actually did, here are the outtakes from the shoot pic.twitter.com/XWYJfMgyZP â€” Jimmy (@JimBoy_Grande) October 15, 2017

While some were proving it was totally possible, it didn't go great for everyone. Please, if you try this at home, perch safely and perhaps under the guidance of an adult supervisor.

Despite some thrills and spills, many found that it was actually possible to replicate the otherwise mind-boggling pose.

So there you have it. That's what the internet has been up to today.
TITLE: People Are Trying To Figure Out If Ariana Grande's 'My Everything' Pose Is Actually Possible
